It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.

<target_code>
Here is the code of get_timeout_millisec_:
```c
static int64_t
get_timeout_millisec_ (struct MHD_Daemon *daemon,
                       int32_t max_timeout)
{
  uint64_t d_timeout;
  mhd_assert (0 <= max_timeout || -1 == max_timeout);
  if (0 == max_timeout)
    return 0;

  if (MHD_NO == MHD_get_timeout64 (daemon, &d_timeout))
    return max_timeout;

  if ((0 < max_timeout) && ((uint64_t) max_timeout < d_timeout))
    return max_timeout;

  if (INT64_MAX <= d_timeout)
    return INT64_MAX;

  return (int64_t) d_timeout;
}
```
</target_code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: The only statements that invoke other functions (and therefore could participate in indirect recursion) are the two calls listed above. No direct call to get_timeout_millisec_ appears in this function. The remaining lines are comparisons, casts, returns and constant checks (e.g. 0 == max_timeout, (uint64_t) max_timeout < d_timeout, INT64_MAX <= d_timeout, and return (int64_t) d_timeout) which do not call any functions and therefore cannot introduce direct or indirect recursion. The INT64_MAX token is a constant macro, and there are no function-pointer invocations or other call sites in the rest of the code fragment that would warrant investigation for Rule 17.2.
